name: briankrebs
tweet: It comes down to having the processes and people to detect and respond to incidents quickly. So many of these ransom attacks devolve into arguments over whether they did backups right. But if you can't see a compromise and/or don't respond quickly enough, backups no longer matter

name: briankrebs
tweet: Pro-tip for managed service providers (& others): Maybe resist the urge to publish press releases when you get large infusions of cash from investors? Kind of makes it hard to claim you can't pay when the ransomware guys come calling. Just a thought.

tweet: This patch for most mere mortals (end users, not enterprise/business users) will be offered as part of a large patch rollup from Microsoft. In this case, the patch is installed alongside a large bundle of updates released today.

name: briankrebs
tweet: ...and CERT's take on CVE-2020-0601: Crypt32.dll fails to validate ECC certificates in a way that properly leverages protections that ECC should provide. name: briankrebs
tweet: Microsoft has released an advisory for this vulnerability in Win10, Server 2016 and '19. It rated this as a "spoofing" flaw that is "important" in severity, but puts exploitability rating at 1, it's second most severe, i.e. "exploitation more likely."  https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-0601 …

name: briankrebs
tweet: Microsoft releases patches on the second Tuesday of each month. That's today. Usually ~1pm ET/10amPT

name: briankrebs
tweet: less than an hour. MS typically starts pushing them out around 1pm ET on Patch Tuesday.

name: briankrebs
tweet: The NSA's Neuberger said this wasn't the first vulnerability the agency has reported to Microsoft, but it was the first one for which they accepted credit/attribution when MS asked.

name: briankrebs
tweet: Sources say this disclosure from NSA is planned to be the first of many as part of a new initiative at NSA dubbed "Turn a New Leaf," aimed at making more of the agency's vulnerability research available to major software vendors and ultimately to the public.

name: briankrebs
tweet: This particular flaw is assigned as CVE-2020-0601. NSA says it exists in Win10 systems from July 2015 onward and Win Server 2016.  My read on that is it's "critical" in those OSes, but may be present and less of a concern in older versions of Windows but we'll know more soon.

name: briankrebs
tweet: Yes, Microsoft will be in just a few hours, along with probably a bunch of other patches that also deserve attention.

tweet: NSA: If enterprise-wide patching of this vuln not possible we recommend prioritize patching systems that perform TLS validation, or host critical infrastructure like domain controllers, DNS servers, VPN servers, etc.

name: briankrebs
tweet: They were asked this direct question but their answer didn't provide much info about the when.

name: briankrebs
tweet: NSA's dir. of cybersecurity Anne Neuberger says the critical cryptographic vulnerability resides in Windows 10 and Windows Server 2016, and that the concern about this particular flaw is that it "makes trust vulnerable."

name: briankrebs
tweet: NSA says they discovered the flaw on their own and that Microsoft will report that MS has seen no active exploitation of this vulnerability so far.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: I was basing it on the Washington post article that said it was an authenticode issue... But I've since learned that the article is wrong, and it is in fact a big deal.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Authenticode bugs are real issues, but nowhere near enough enough to justify a hype train, we get bigger bugs than that every patch Tuesday. This is not limited to code signing, and therefore I think a little hype train can be forgiven.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: I'm reliably informed that the washington post don't know what they're talking about, it's not an authenticode issue, and is in fact a big deal. https://twitter.com/taviso/status/1217114527688318976 …

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: This washington post article says it's an authenticode flaw, that doesn't get my attention. If it's all TLS certs, that's potentially more interesting. https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/nsa-found-a-dangerous-microsoft-software-flaw-and-alerted-the-firm--rather-than-weaponize-it/2020/01/14/f024c926-3679-11ea-bb7b-265f4554af6d_story.html …

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Booo seems pretty boring. If it's not an RCE, don't sell me tickets for the hype train 😛

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Now we're talking 😂

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: There was a bug recently where some oddball oid allowed local privilege escalation, and I know of a few others with weird behaviour. That wouldn't be a "spoof source of digitally signed software" though, so curious if that was a quote or Brian extrapolating.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: I would hope it's at least a memory corruption parsing ASN.1/X.509/etc if people are panicking, if its just an authenticode defeat.... Then meh 🤷�♂�

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Did they say "spoof the source of digitally signed software", or is that your theory? I don't think authenticode flaws are particularly exciting, there are code execution vulns just *parsing* PE occasionally.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Sorry to hear that, that sucks. I guess you know my position on this topic, but I'm still sorry it happened to you.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Disagree, even then SMS 2FA makes zero sense, it's a phishable solution to phishing. That's just bananas. People argue it still has some value impeding credential stuffing. Sure, all those password reusers who aren't vulnerable to phishing, all zero of them.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: What is your understanding of the system being discussed here? I can't get my understanding to jell with your criticism, couldn't you say exactly the same thing if the system *wasn't* privacy preserving?

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: What's the problem? I think maybe you're talking about the cleanup tool, I don't like it but this seems like a dishonest description of it. Here's a thread about it. https://twitter.com/justinschuh/status/980503968500494336 …

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: They're really bad and dumb for sure, but I was thinking more pants-on-head bananas like good av bugs 🤪 🤡

tweet: Yeah, a good example is it's basically impossible to mention localhost without some authoritative sounding jerk confidently explaining that it's only exploitable locally. Then I have to explain that's not how it works, or people think I've been corrected and it's non-issue 😓

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: I dunno, I get a lot of disinformation in my replies, and then I feel obligated to explain them.. Kinda feel like it might just even out.

tweet: I think it almost certainly does, seems unlikely they're going to close down the business... 🤷�♂� I just hope it's not even worse (SSL interception, browser code injection, etc)

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: How will they continue to provide their subsidiary with data?

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: I had this discussion with Daniel B once, he was amazed all the drama around disclosure because in crypto full disclosure is the norm. Maybe we'll catch up one day 😛

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: That's you're opinion, but the diabetic probably disagrees. You know some people disable spectre mitigations because perf is more important? Everyone's different.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: That's certainly true of some people, but it's not true of all people. A diabetic has very specific dietary requirements for example, and would not want the waiter to choose for them.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: How lucky customers are that you know what's best for them.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Okay, fair enough, I guess we'll see - I think we have pretty good data that PZ, for example, has been able to adjust patch times. 🙂

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: I dunno, it sure seems to bother Mary Anne what I do 😛

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Yes, you've said lots of contradictory things. You're opposed to full disclosure, but want more information.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Dude, engineering isn't free, it's expensive. The only way to get that money spent is to tweak incentives so that it makes economic sense. That's not a critique of capitalism. I get that vendors don't like external people trying to tweak those incentives, but too bad.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Cool, and the best way to get that is to give users less information about vulnerabilities that affect them?

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: I think they don't tell you which vulnerabilities they want you to prioritise, and how fast they expect you to respond - because they don't know what vulnerabilities you're sitting on privately.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Firstly, with enough resources you don't have to compromise, agreed? How will you get those resources? Secondly, I want customers to tell you what balance they want, not for you to decide for them.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: What I'm telling you is that unless users have enough information to tell you what they expect, you're effectively saying "please trust this capitalist institution to do the right thing, which is very expensive, without any incentives to do so".

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Then what is it you want? More information available to users, but delayed until it is no longer useful?

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: You can use any metrics you want, but how long you leave your users vulnerable seems like an important one.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: That's nonsense, how can the market react to information that you're arguing they shouldn't know? I'm saying make it public and let the market decide. You're saying don't let the market know, just trust us to do the right thing.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Hmmm, but isn't your argument that we should just accept the amount of time that patch qualification takes based on resources assigned by some executive bean counter, and not try to influence that?

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: It doesn't get lost, the cost of those moving parts isn't a universal physical constant- we can make them more efficient, but that costs money. Why do that without an incentive?

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Sure, but the problem with this is two fold. First, not everyone agrees you should be allowed to adjust those knobs on their behalf, you don't know their priorities. Second, you don't have the power to adjust them, you need resources provided by people who don't have a dev heart.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: I don't really know what that means, but I don't like the publicly traded company doesn't need any incentives to do the right thing narrative.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: I think everyone is clear that vendors don't like full disclosure 😛

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Dude, you're making it really hard to avoid having a disclosure debate with you. What you call "0day policy" others call full disclosure, is that really a discussion you want to get into? 😛

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: The only difference with this changes is less information. Therefore, patches that would have been prioritized with context will not be. In my opinion, that is waiting more.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: You're missing the point. You don't consider it an issue unless it's delayed beyond what it would have been without context. We don't agree that is a good bar.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Break a leg!

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: People are waiting already, unless they're going to wait even more, you don't consider it a problem?

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: The point is that "you don't need any information, we've made the decision for you, just be a passive consumer" does delay scheduled events. With more complete information, the appropriate schedule can be determined.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: No, the problem is patching is disruptive. Knowing why you're being disrupted and being able to understand and reason about the risks allows you to make better decisions.

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Welcome to the club 😛

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: I think it's more "standard qualification takes 3 months, see no reason to put my neck on the line and let this one jump the queue, that's a lot of paperwork"

name: Tavis Ormandy
tweet: Ah, we're well staffed and the difference between prioritized and not is small, but I think we're the exception. I've heard gov change management horror stories, for example.

name: Dan Goodin
tweet: GnuPG developers still insist that SHA1 is broken only in an "extremely narrow sense." Attacks only get better, and for all we know, real-world adversaries may already have more advanced exploits. https://twitter.com/matthew_d_green/status/1214573983087108097 …

name: Dan Goodin
tweet: The 2012 Flame collision attack may have needed $200,000 worth of computing power  https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2012/06/flame-crypto-attack-may-have-needed-massive-compute-power/ …). The new SHA1 attack costs just $11,000. If attackers have a reason to achieve a chosen prefix attack against SHA1, there's nothing stopping them.

name: Dan Goodin
tweet: PGP certificate authority CAcert still uses it, as does the GIT software versioning system. SHA1 is a ticking time bomb. Developers should jettison it ASAP lest we see another Flame-style attack in the wild.

name: Dan Goodin
tweet: Despite near unanimous consensus among cryptographers that SHA1 is completely broken, lots of developers continue to rely on it. GnuPG only moved away from it in November, after the researchers privately reported their results.

name: Dan Goodin
tweet: A chosen prefix collision is a much more powerful exploit. It's what the Flame espionage malware used in 2012 against MD5 to hijack Microsoft's Windows update system. The researchers behind the new exploit used it to achieve a PGP impersonation attack.

name: Dan Goodin
tweet: Researchers declared SHA1 dead 3 years ago after achieving the world's first known collision attack against it. This new attack, a chosen prefix collision, is even more devastating to the hash function.

name: Dan Goodin

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
They can’t help with everything though, & nobody should think it’s appropriate for them to do so.
They have to prioritize for vulnerabilities affecting national security or critical infrastructure.
They will not coordinate disclosure for all bugs.
Nobody does.
Nobody should.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Muting this disclosure nerd snipe of a thread.
My opinion here is:
Researchers having trouble with disclosure? Cut your losses & move on.
Don’t do all this extra detective work.
If it’s really that important & the vendor doesn’t seem to care, fork it over to @certcc for help.
FIN https://twitter.com/SushiDude/status/1216888748870381570 …

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Not really the place for researchers to *start* when they have a vulnerability, no.
Literally introducing a government middle man isn’t even recommended by the folks who run @certcc 
That is also not what vendors who have their own process want as the 1st step reporting either. pic.twitter.com/7qsgeJqpgE

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet: Very nice!!

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet: If this was for the researcher side of disclosure, why did you give this talk at Oracle? Real q, not trolling.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
The ISO standards are available at no cost to vendors. Vendors are heavily resourced, or should build towards having a capability to handle bug reports.
Researchers should focus on working with vendors who are already in the Acceptance Stage of the 5 Stages of Vuln Response Grief

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
I’d like to see less free/underpaid labor in the form of detective work by researchers though, not the creation of more detailed guides on how to waste researchers’ valuable time.
Good faith effort doesn’t = free labor.
That’s why I’ve concentrated my effort on bettering vendors.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Yup, still boils down to:
1. Find a contact at the affected vendor
2. Tell that contact what the vulnerability is

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Advice I give to researchers having trouble with disclosure is:
If the vendor won’t listen, your choices are to walk away, publicly disclose, or try to find a buyer.
Banging your head against an unresponsive vendor is a waste of your time.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Such as:
Asking for a bounty always equals extortion.
(It doesn’t)
Go to Twitter or share w media if you want a faster/better response.
(Might backfire)
The list goes on.

Should be simple.
Find a contact.
Get help from @EFF if they threaten legally.
Not sure what else is needed.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
The advice is generic & not complicated though, & what you know annoys me to no end is the LET’S OVERCOMPLICATE & REWRITE THE WHEEL stuff that keeps fogging over existing work in this space.
For example, if someone decides to “create� this guide, it’s likely to feature bad advice

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Same, Mike. 5 years old riding the public bus both to and from school.
My single mom had to leave much earlier than me to get to work on time via public transportation herself before we owned a car.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet: I gave generic advice though. What about that was individualized?

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
For example, UK law is much stricter & requires explicit prior authorization to not be technically illegal.
Putting out researcher guidelines should not make it seem like there’s  some magical universal “safe harbor� rules that grant “hacklomatic immunity� in all jurisdictions.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
The bounty companies have guides for researchers to use on their platforms.
Since not every research target is on a bounty platform, it usually comes down to finding the right contact & following the vendor’s guidelines if any.
Non-US researchers may be subject to different laws.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet: I came here to say this 👆�

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet: Thank you for answering when hackers come to report vulns to you. :)

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet: If they didn’t, then your employer isn’t on their bug acquisition list. They don’t buy all bugs, only those that their customers need ZDI product IDS/IPS signatures for.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Your feelings are valid based on your experience.
I disagreed w your blanket statement that painted your feelings as undisputed facts about asking about bounties automatically being extortion.
I gave an example of why I disagreed.
We’ve both made our points & I wish you good day.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
I’m not going to argue w how you feel.
The fact that you don’t know that it is ZDI’s business model to inform vendors of vulns at no cost over its well-documented 15 year history might indicate that you’re still very new to receiving reports & your feelings may evolve over time.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
In order to preserve their ability to get paid by ZDI, a bug has to be (to the best of the finder’s knowledge) unknown to the vendor.
So there could be no disclosure before asking that very reasonable question first, or the finder would not be eligible for payment from anyone.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Great example of non-extortion bounty questions:

Before I launched MIcrosoft’s bounties, finders would ask us if we had a bounty yet & since we said no, they would very reasonably state that they would then be going through ZDI instead to get paid.

Not extortion, totally legit.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Completely disagree on the blanket statement there.
It’s perfectly reasonable to ask up front & decide to disclose or not from there.
Why should bug hunters not get paid if they can?
Nothing wrong with asking.
It’s not extortion unless it’s actual extortion.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
No, you’re fine! What you did is fine too, totally a legit thing to ask a vendor you’ve had delays w their official channel.
Just trying to help newbs avoid accidentally enraging an inexperienced vendor who’s going through this is what we’re illustrating: https://youtu.be/T6e70upcfl4

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Also to be clear, I’m not saying what you’re doing is “bad� but that seeking the official disclosure channel is considered by vendors to be the preferred neutral/friendly approach.
Newbs should try the front door first is all I’m saying, since this is a thread for newbs.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet: This thread is for newbs, not about @citrix specifically.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet: Note that a mature vendor has scripts for its social media folks to hand off & redirect public inquiries around vuln disclosure, but inexperienced vendors might overreact with lawyers, attempt to attack the researcher, or simply mistake a reasonable bounty question for extortion.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
The above is a neutral/friendly way to start a conversation.
Some folks go straight to twitter for their own expedience, but newbs should know that this may cause the vendor to overreact to that approach, especially if the vendor is new to vuln disclosure.
 https://t.co/ZaordLvtA7  https://twitter.com/dcuthbert/status/1217107873022517248?s=21 …

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
But how will they know to improve their actual intake process if you don’t use it?
The person running the social media account should be using a script to route you back to the correct security reporting path anyway.
I get using Twitter if you can’t find a door to knock on at all

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet: Autocorrect did me some violence in that last tweet of mine. Glad you knew what I meant!

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Why wouldn’t you just ask them via their designated security reporting email address?
Not trolling, genuinely curious about why you’d ask publicly, when their security contact is the first google hit? pic.twitter.com/Z9gm0BmuTu

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet: There are used in some bug bounties to help identify supposedly friendly web attack traffic from bug bounty hunters, to alot incident responders to focus on real attacks instead of investigating bug hunting activity which would otherwise look about the same as a real attack.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
When legal threats to researchers trying to disclose vulnerabilities happen, best to contact @EFF .

That’s pretty much it. 

Was there something more specific they need to know?

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
Just know that if it was hard already to even tell that vendor, be prepared for the rest of the experience to be bumpy as well.
Short of vendor legal threats, but clearly going poorly, a finder could send the vendor this video: 
 https://youtu.be/-L3DNZtK8lc 
Or https://youtu.be/T6e70upcfl4

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet: If they still can’t find a security-specific contact, & they still want to disclose to that vendor, they could just send it to whatever support contact they can find, along w a pointer to ISO 29147 for that vendor who clearly hasn’t implemented the standard, yet & go from there.

name: Katie Moussouris
tweet:
The next step (if they choose to report it) is to find a security contact at the affected vendor(s).

If they can’t find one, they can try:
Security@
Secure@
Support@ etc Email addresses

Or they can look on LinkedIn or tweet at the vendor to ask them for a security contact.

tweet: #speeddial for sure!!

tweet:
I haven't realized I had ADD until I had my child diagnosed five years ago and the doctor mentioned my symptoms.
